column2: While talking with you one day, a servant asks you why we need to have Jews at your court. “Surely,” he says, “You are aware of the danger of these terrible people? We shouldn’t be keeping them here.”
column3: Un jour, un serviteur vous demande pourquoi nous avons besoin d'avoir des Juifs à votre cour. "Vous êtes conscients du danger de ces terribles gens ? On ne devrait pas les garder ici."

column2: While talking with you one day, a servant asks you why we need to have Jews at your court. “Surely,” he says, “You are aware of the danger of these terrible people? We shouldn’t be keeping them here.”

One of my Jewish courtiers is well-known for his great knowledge concerning spiritual matters. Today, out of boredom, we decided to begin a religious debate. So far, it’s been interesting debating against a Jew. As of now, things are starting to get really heated...

One of my Jewish courtiers is well-known for his great knowledge concerning spiritual matters. Today, out of boredom, we decided to begin a religious debate. So far, it’s been interesting debating against a Jew. As of now, things are starting to get really heated...
column3: Un de mes courtisans juifs est connu pour sa grande connaissance des questions spirituelles. Aujourd'hui, par ennui, nous avons décidé d'entamer un débat religieux. Jusqu'à présent, ça a été un débat intéressant contre un Juif. À partir de maintenant, les choses commencent à s'échauffer ...

column2: While we disagreed on many points, our dicussion was nevertheless very enlightening. In fact, we were so engrossed in our debate that by the time we finished, it was already sunrise!
While we disagreed on many points, our discussion was nevertheless very enlightening. In fact, we were so engrossed in our debate that by the time we finished, it was already sunrise!
column3: Bien que nous ayons été en désaccord sur de nombreux points, notre discussion a néanmoins été très éclairante. En fait, nous étions tellement absorbés par notre débat qu'au moment où nous avons terminé, le soleil était déjà levé !

column2: I should never have this kind of debate again. Our disagreements were too many, and I really felt frustrated with the man.
I should never have this kind of debate again. Our disagreements were too many, and I really felt frustrated with the man.
column3: Je ne devrais plus jamais avoir ce genre de débat. Nos désaccords étaient trop nombreux, et je me sentais vraiment frustré avec cet homme.

column2: It’s such a nice day outside, but even as I bask in the garden’s sunlight, inside my heart I feel sorrow. Perhaps I should sing the song my mother taught me years ago...
It’s such a nice day outside, but even as I bask in the garden’s sunlight, inside my heart I feel sorrow. Perhaps I should sing the song my mother taught me years ago...
column3: C'est une si belle journée à l'extérieur, mais même si je me prélasse dans le soleil du jardin, à l'intérieur de mon cœur, je ressens de la peine. Je devrais peut-être chanter la chanson que ma mère m'a apprise il y a des années ...

column2: Today, while walking in the courtyard, you find one of your Jewish courtiers singing a haunting, ancient Jewish song. Even though you don’t understand it, you feel the sadness, the melancholy, the nostalgia, the sehnsucht of the lyrics. You watch her sing for a while, and after she finishes, you decide to approach her.

Today, while walking in the courtyard, you find one of your Jewish courtiers singing a haunting, ancient Jewish song. Even though you don’t understand it, you feel the sadness, the melancholy, the nostalgia, the sehnsucht of the lyrics. You watch her sing for a while, and after she finishes, you decide to approach her.
column3: Aujourd'hui, en marchant dans la cour, vous trouvez un de vos courtisans juifs qui chante une chanson juive ancienne et obsédante. Même si vous ne le comprenez pas, vous ressentez la tristesse, la mélancolie, la nostalgie, l'aspiration des paroles. Vous la regardez chanter un moment, et une fois qu'elle a fini, vous décidez de l'approcher.

column2: While talking with my liege today, the topic of our conversation suddenly switched to finances. Perhaps this is a perfect opportunity to make my request!
While talking with my liege today, the topic of our conversation suddenly switched to finances. Perhaps this is a perfect opportunity to make my request!
column3: En parlant avec mon seigneur aujourd'hui, le sujet de notre conversation a soudainement basculé sur les finances. C'est peut-être l'occasion rêvée de faire ma demande !

column2: While privately discussing the finances  of your realm with one of your Jewish courtiers, the courtier suddenly makes a request. Nervously, he says: “My liege, the Jewish people are suffering greatly this year, being forced to pay the Jizya tax when we are in such an impoverished situation. To alleviate the problems of the Jewry, would it hurt to slightly reduce this tax?”
column3: Alors que vous discutez en privé des finances de votre royaume avec l'un de vos courtisans juifs, le courtisan fait soudainement une demande. Nerveux, il dit : "Mon seigneur, le peuple juif souffre énormément cette année, étant forcé de payer l'impôt de Jizya alors que nous sommes dans une situation si pauvre. Pour atténuer les problèmes des Juifs, est-ce que ça ne serait pas bien de réduire légèrement cette taxe ?"

column2: While privately discussing the finances  of your realm with one of your Jewish courtiers, the courtier suddenly makes a request. Nervously, he says: “My liege, the Jewish people are suffering greatly this year, being forced to pay the Jizya tax when we are in such an impoverished situation. To alleviate the problems of the Jewry, would it hurt to slightly reduce this tax?”

After having a number of Jews in my court for such a long time, I’ve gotten to know them better, and I’ve begun to reconsider my hatred of them. Hath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions as a Christian has? Perhaps Jews can be good and just people too.

After having a number of Jews in my court for such a long time, I’ve gotten to know them better, and I’ve begun to reconsider my hatred of them. Hath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions as a Christian has? Perhaps Jews can be good and just people too.
column3: Après avoir eu un certain nombre de Juifs dans ma cour pendant si longtemps, j'ai appris à mieux les connaître et j'ai commencé à reconsidérer ma haine envers eux. N'est-ce pas un regard juif ? N'a-t-on pas des mains, des organes, des dimensions, des sens, des affections, des passions juives comme un chrétien ? Peut-être que les Juifs peuvent être bons et justes aussi.

column2: I’ve just received news that one of my distant cousins is fleeing from persecution in another region. I could take my cousin in, but I’m not sure if my liege is willing too... I’ll just have to wait for a good opportunity to ask.

I’ve just received news that one of my distant cousins is fleeing from persecution in another region. I could take my cousin in, but I’m not sure if my liege is willing too... I’ll just have to wait for a good opportunity to ask.
column3: Je viens d'apprendre qu'un de mes cousins éloignés fuit la persécution dans une autre région. Je pourrais faire entrer mon cousin, mais je ne suis pas sûr que mon seigneur le veuille aussi... Je vais devoir attendre une bonne occasion de demander.

column2: A Jewish courtier, [From.GetFirstName], has recently requested that you allow a distant cousins to take refuge in your court. This cousin is trying to flee persecution from another realm, and currently your realm is the only place this cousin could go to... if you allow him to, that is.

A Jewish courtier, [From.GetFirstName], has recently requested that you allow a distant cousins to take refuge in your court. This cousin is trying to flee persecution from another realm, and currently your realm is the only place this cousin could go to... if you allow him to, that is.
column3: Un courtisan juif, [From.GetFirstName], a récemment demandé que vous autorisiez un cousin éloigné à se réfugier dans votre cour. Ce cousin essaie de fuir la persécution d'un autre royaume, et actuellement votre royaume est le seul endroit où ce cousin pourrait aller... si vous le lui permettez.

column2: My liege is currently very sick, but I know a skilled Jewish physician - a family friend, in fact - who lives in my neighborhood. Perhaps I can recommend him to my liege.
My liege is currently very sick, but I know a skilled Jewish physician - a family friend, in fact - who lives in my neighborhood. Perhaps I can recommend him to my liege.
column3: Mon seigneur est actuellement très malade, mais je connais un médecin juif compétent - un ami de la famille, en fait - qui vit dans mon quartier. Je peux peut-être le recommander à mon seigneur.

column2: Your illness continues to worsen. However, [From.GetFirstName] tells you of a skilled Jewish physician he knows very well (apparently this man is a family friend). This physician could, hopefully, claims your courtier, heal you of your illness.

Your illness continues to worsen. However, [From.GetFirstName] tells you of a skilled Jewish physician he knows very well (apparently this man is a family friend). This physician could, hopefully, claims your courtier, heal you of your illness.
column3: Votre maladie continue de s'aggraver. Cependant, [From.GetFirstName]  vous parle d'un médecin juif compétent qu'il connaît très bien (apparemment, cet homme est un ami de la famille). Votre courtisan, espérons-le, prétend que le médecin pourrait vous guérir de votre maladie.

column2: Apparently, the Jewish physician is just as skilled as your courtier said. Your illness has completely gone away, and you feel even stronger than you were before your illness started. This must be a miracle of sorts!

Apparently, the Jewish physician is just as skilled as your courtier said. Your illness has completely gone away, and you feel even stronger than you were before your illness started. This must be a miracle of sorts!
column3: Apparemment, le médecin juif est aussi compétent que votre courtisan l'a dit. Votre maladie a complètement disparu et vous vous sentez encore plus fort qu'avant le début de votre maladie. Ce doit être une sorte de miracle !

column2: The Jewish physician tries hardest to cure your illness, but it seems nothing he does seem to help. Still, you do feel a little better than you did before, at the least.
The Jewish physician tries hardest to cure your illness, but it seems nothing he does seem to help. Still, you do feel a little better than you did before, at the least.
column3: Le médecin juif fait de son mieux pour guérir votre maladie, mais il semblerait que rien ne l'aider. Vous vous sentez quand même un peu mieux qu'avant, au moins.

column2: One of my Jewish courtiers has just returned from the funeral of a family friend. Perhaps I should offer my condolences.
One of my Jewish courtiers has just returned from the funeral of a family friend. Perhaps I should offer my condolences.
column3: Un de mes courtisans juifs vient de rentrer des funérailles d'un ami de la famille. Je devrais peut-être lui offrir mes condoléances.

column2: You are not a descendant of David, and your claim is not recognized. With the end of the exilarchs the Karaites now look to different leaders.
Some of our Jewish subjects have expressed a desire to serve at court.
We need educated people, no matter what.
We need educated people, no matter what.
column3: Nous avons besoin de gens instruits, quoi qu'il arrive.

column2: But you see, in [Root.Religion.GetScriptureName], it says that...
But you see, in [Root.Religion.GetScriptureName], it says that...
column3: Mais vous voyez, dans [Root.Religion.GetScriptureName], il est écrit que ...

column2: It was most enjoyable.
It was most enjoyable.
column3: C'était très agréable.

column2: Enough of this.
Enough of this.
column3: Assez de tout ça.

column2: Oh Jerusalem...
Oh Jerusalem...
column3: Oh Jérusalem ...

column2: Very soothing and soulful indeed!
Very soothing and soulful indeed!
column3: Très apaisant et émouvant en effet !

column2: Hopefully my liege is in a good mood...
Hopefully my liege is in a good mood...
column3: J'espère que mon seigneur est de bonne humeur ...

column2: Very well. I will temporarily reduce taxes.
Very well. I will temporarily reduce taxes.
column3: Très bien. Je vais réduire temporairement les impôts.

column2: No! Such ideas are deceptions by the devil!
No! Such ideas are deceptions by the devil!
column3: Non ! De telles idées sont des tromperies du diable !

column2: Oy vey...
Oy vey...
column3: Oy vey ...

column2: Very well. As long as he doesn’t cause trouble.
Very well. As long as he doesn’t cause trouble.
column3: Très bien. Tant qu'il ne cause pas d'ennuis.

column2: Hopefully my liege will be accept a Jewish physician.
Hopefully my liege will be accept a Jewish physician.
column3: J'espère que mon seigneur acceptera un médecin juif.

column2: Thank you for telling me this. Summon this physician!
Thank you for telling me this. Summon this physician!
column3: Merci de me l'avoir dit. Appelez ce médecin !

column2: Thank [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName] for the physician! Here’s his payment.
Thank [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName] for the physician! Here’s his payment.
column3: Remercions [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName] pour ce médecin ! Voilà son paiement.

column2: Oh well. Thank you, nevertheless, my good man.
Oh well. Thank you, nevertheless, my good man.
column3: Oh, eh bien. Merci quand même, mon brave homme.

column2: I am sorry for your loss.
I am sorry for your loss.
column3: Toutes mes condoléances.

column2: They will regret this!
We'll find jobs for them.
I don’t like them either, but we need them for now.
I don’t like them either, but we need them for now.
column3: Je ne les aime pas non plus, mais on en a besoin pour l'instant.

column2: It sounds terrible, actually.
It sounds terrible, actually.
column3: Ça a l'air terrible, en fait.

column2: No. Be thankful I don’t treat you like the Christians do.
No. Be thankful I don’t treat you like the Christians do.
column3: Non. Sois reconnaissant que je ne te traite pas comme les chrétiens.

column2: Perhaps I shouldn’t be so hardheaded about these matters...
Perhaps I shouldn’t be so hardheaded about these matters...
column3: Peut-être que je ne devrais pas être si intransigeant sur ces questions ...

column2: I can help provide him a temporary home in the city.
I can help provide him a temporary home in the city.
column3: Je peux l'aider à lui trouver un foyer temporaire en ville.

column2: No! I don’t want that sort of man near me!
No! I don’t want that sort of man near me!
column3: Non ! Je ne veux pas de ce genre d'homme près de moi !

column2: Please give the physician this gift along with payment.
Please give the physician this gift along with payment.
column3: S'il vous plaît, donner au médecin ce cadeau avec le paiement.

column2: Fool! Get out! I knew I should have never trusted you!
Fool! Get out! I knew I should have never trusted you!
column3: Imbécile ! Sors de là ! Je savais que je n'aurais jamais dû vous faire confiance !

column2: You should think about converting now, before it’s too late!
You should think about converting now, before it’s too late!
column3: Vous devriez penser à vous convertir maintenant, avant qu'il ne soit trop tard !

column2: Don’t disrespect any of my subjects, even if they are Jews.
Don’t disrespect any of my subjects, even if they are Jews.
column3: Ne manquez pas de respect à aucun de mes sujets, même s'ils sont juifs.

column2: Actually, I should not be deceived by the music of the Jews.
Actually, I should not be deceived by the music of the Jews.
column3: En fait, je ne devrais pas être trompé par la musique des Juifs.

column2: We’re all children of God, after all...
We’re all children of God, after all...
column3: Nous sommes tous enfants de Dieu, après tout ...

column2: I already have enough of your kind here!
I already have enough of your kind here!
column3: J'en ai déjà assez de votre espèce !

column2: Request the physician that he stay in my court.
Request the physician that he stay in my court.
column3: Demandez au médecin de rester dans ma cour.

column2: Imprison and torture the man! He must be trying to kill me!
Imprison and torture the man! He must be trying to kill me!
column3: Emprisonnez et torturez l'homme ! Il a essayé de me tuer !

column2: You should have no more tza’ar and only have simchas.
You should have no more tza’ar and only have simchas.
column3: Vous ne devriez plus avoir de tza'ar et seulement des simchas.

column2: Wait, I do understand your language. The song is sad, indeed...
Wait, I do understand your language. The song is sad, indeed...
column3: Attendez, je comprends votre langage. La chanson est triste, en effet ...

column2: As a just ruler, I must treat all subjects equally, based on their merits.
As a just ruler, I must treat all subjects equally, based on their merits.
column3: En tant que dirigeant juste, je dois traiter tous les sujets sur un pied d'égalité, en fonction de leurs mérites.

column2: Debate ends well
Debate ends well
column3: Le débat se termine bien

column2: Debate ends badly
Debate ends badly
column3: Le débat se termine mal

column2: Exilarch
Adonai
HaShem
Shema
Milkhemet Reshut
Kohen Gadol
Your Holiness
The Torah
So begins a new chapter in the history of the Jewish people...

You have done the impossible and restored the holy land to Jewish rule. Someday, perhaps soon, Jews all over the world will speak your name in awe and honor you as a hero in the vein of Moses, David, or Judah Maccabee. The future of this new Kingdom of Israel is far from certain, for we are surrounded by enemeies near and far, but at least we know that today, [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName] has delivered.
Israel Restored
Only time will tell what happens next.

We have successfully conquered Israel from the heathen Jews. The Kingdom of Israel, as a concept, is not relevant to our people, so it shall now be known as the Kingdom of Jerusalem again. Shall the Jews reclaim the now-destroyed Israel, or shall Israel once again fade away, a distant memory kept alive by the dreams of the Jewish people?
The Jews Lose Israel
We shall one day reclaim Israel, somehow.

Tragedy descends once more upon the Chosen People! We Jews remember when Jerusalem was sacked - first by the Babylonians and second by the Romans. Now, it seems that history has repeated itself as the Kingdom of Israel falls to our enemies.\n\nWhat injustice have we done in the past to deserve this? Surely, the ways of Yahweh are mysterious, but to lose Israel again is shocking and catastrophic indeed. Still, we have survived terrible situations before, and we shall survive this one as well.
Israel Lost!
We will set aside some funding and support as soon as we can!

Some Jews ‘making aliyah,’ or returning to Israel, have considerable military experience. Some of these men wish to form a special military unit, the "Shield of the Third Temple" - utilizing their diverse backgrounds and abilities, this ragtag band of unlikely heroes can defend Israel from its enemies. They now simply need our support.
Defenders of Israel?
Very well. As long as they aren’t useless schmucks!
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Ashkenazi Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from parts of Europe, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
They can certainly stay with us, their skills will be of most use.
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Sephardic Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from Iberia and North Africa, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
Good. May they find themselves welcome here.
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Mizrahi Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from parts of the Middle East, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
I see. I think there is a place for them at my court.
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Crimean Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from the steppe regions such as Crimea, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
Hopefully their skills can help us. Welcome them!
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Bukhari Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from Central Asia, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
It is a long and arduous journey from India! Let’s welcome them.
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Indian Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from India, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
Amazing that we Jews have reached as far as China. Welcome them!
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Chinese Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from China, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
Alright. I will accept them into my court.
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Falashim or Ethiopian Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from East Africa, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
Interesting. I will take them in.
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Romaniote Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from the Balkans and Anatolia, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
I gladly welcome them into my court.
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Maghreb Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from North and West Africa, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
Interesting.

My relative, who has recently restored Israel to the Jewish people, now claims descent from David. Being part of this dynasty, I too can now proudly proclaim my descent from such an illustrious figure.
Yes, I think it’s important we find this “proof.”
No, I cannot fabricate such a thing, it goes against my conscience.

My dynasty has done the impossible. We have restored Israel to the Jewish people. Many of my advisors, however, believe it is important I find “proof” that I am descended from King David. It would legitimize my rule even more.
The House of David
Welcome! Welcome!
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Caucasian Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from the Caucasus region, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
They are unique Jews indeed - let us welcome them!
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Yemenite Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from the southern parts of the Arabian peninsula, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.
Good, good. Let them stay.
I can’t take them in, but they can settle in Israel as they please.

Since the restoration of Israel, many of our fellow Jews from around the world have “made aliyah,” or returned, to Israel. Today, a group of Italki, or Italian Jews, having recently arrived in Israel from the Italian peninsula, wish to make use of their talents and serve in your court.

Claim Descent of David
Perhaps I should strengthen my legitimacy as King of Israel by claiming descent from this illustrious figure...
The Exilarchy
The Karaite Exilarchy
Shield of the Third Temple
The Temple
High Priestly
Ar-Garizim
High Priestly
I've found a suitable bride.
As Exilarch, it is important I get married if I want to continue the noble lineage of King David!
Terrible news.
Terrible news!
I see...
The line of the Jewish Exilarchs has died out. These men, descended from the ancient and mighty King David, and who led the Diaspora through centuries of struggle, are no more.
The Jewish Exilarchy Ends
Terrible news.
Terrible news!
I see...
The line of the Karaite Exilarchs has died out. These men, descended from the ancient and mighty King David, and who led the Diaspora through centuries of struggle, are no more.
The Karaite Exilarchy Ends
xxxxx
xxxxx
Oy vey, what is this!
As exilarch, I'm supposed to be Jewish!
I reclaimed Israel, not they!

Israel is restored, and many Jews are returning to the promised land. Among these Jews are the Exilarchs, descendants of King David, who supposedly led the Jewish people during the diaspora. They may not have led Israel to victory, but they may pose a threat in the future, as they are of the House of David.
When the opportunity comes...
Why is it that we, the descendants of King David, languish when this pretender sits on the throne of Israel? Someday, we shall reclaim our birthright! Someday...
The karaites are boring anyway
With the death of the pretender karaite exilarch, the next in line to claim its exilarchy happens to be me. Well, a good chance as any to be rid of it
I wonder what the Talmud advices, oh right, I don't care!
With the death of the pompous exilarch, the next in line to claim the exilarchy happens to be me. Well, a good chance as any to be rid of it
I am the exilarch!

Altough the exilarchy has been extinguished for one reason or another, my birthright as a member of the house of David, my eloquent speeches and my mastery of the Talmud have won me many supporters who claim I should take the mantle of exilarch. Clearly a great future awaits me!
I am the exilarch!

Altough the exilarchy has been extinguished for one reason or another, my birthright as a member of the house of David, my eloquent speeches and my mastery of the Torah have won me many supporters who claim I should take the mantle of karaite exilarch. Clearly a great future awaits me!
Falashim
House of David
This character is supposedly descended from the great king of Israel, David.
Has sufficient numbers of capable military men from aliyah (i.e. has seen relevent event)
Can now form a special holy order vassalized to the Kingdom of Israel via decision
Restorer of Israel
This character has, against all odds, reclaimed the promised land, Israel, to Jewish rule.
Mainstream Judaism.
I'm about to get married. Hopefully this girl won't be as forceful as my dear mother!
Oy vey!
One of your Jewish courtiers, [From.GetFirstName], is no longer a bachelor. After a traditional Jewish wedding, he is now married to lovely young Jewish woman, who will now join your court.
Mazel tov!
Chief Rabbi
Judaeo-Christian
A generic heresy encompassing the judaeochristians.
Judaic

column2: Mizrahim
Observe Passover
Host a major Passover event to commemorate when our Jewish ancestors, under Moses' guidance, left Egypt and journeyed to the Holy Land.
Observed Passover
Recruit Elite Israelite Unit
Recruit a group of experienced Jewish warriors from around the world into an elite unit, answerable only to the ruler of Israel
Should I burn my Chametz or sell it...

As the Lord commanded to us, it is time that we observe Passover. This year, I will host a much larger affair than usual at my court. Preparations are well under way. For instance, everyone at court is searching for Chametz, or leaven, and figuring out different ways of disposing it.
I think we’re almost finished here.

It is now the night before Passover. As head of my court, it is proper that I partake in one final, formal search for Chametz. With all the lights blown out, save for the candle I hold in my hands, I scour my castle with utmost diligence and attention, making sure there is no Chametz remaining, whether it is in the kitchens, my bedroom, or my servant’s quarters. If by misfortune any are remaining tomorrow, when Passover begins, I will make sure to burn it while repeating the declaration of biyur chametz, declaring any chametz that may not have been found to be null and void "as the dust of the earth".
Removing the Chametz
We must continue our preparations.
Let us begin by drinking four cups of wine.

It is the first night of Passover, and I and my court have gathered for a special dinner called “seder.” During the meal, the story of our exodus from Egypt is retold, word for word, from the text of the Haggadah.
Tomorrow morning, Passover will formally begin!
“Let me answer that...”

During the seder, it is customary to have a ritualized question and answer session, where young sons inquire about the entirety of Passover. One of the children asks the first question, “Why is this night different from all other nights?” And so I reply:
The question and answer session continues, and ends with the singing of songs and prayers. “Next year in Jerusalem!” I say (as is custom), with conviction.
The Chosen People shall endure so long as [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName] wills it.

During the past few days, while observing Passover, I have constantly contemplated the story of exodus - the suffering and miseries your ancestors suffered from the tyrannical Egyptians, and how they left under the guidance of Moses. In a way, it helps keeps things in perspective.
All will hear of the plight of our ancestors as they left Egypt for the promised land.
Now, let us sing songs of praise to [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName]!

It is the seventh and final day of Passover, or “Shvi'i shel Pesach” in Hebrew. Everyone in my court gathers for a large, festive meal. At the table are delicious foods, cooked specifically for Passover.\nToday, we commemorate the day our ancestors escaped Egypt when Moses split the Red Sea apart before drowning all of Pharaoh’s warriors. A great day it was, and a sign of [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName]’s watchful eye over the Children of Israel, as the holy men are wont to remind all of us.
Shvi'i shel Pesach
Passover continues.
And now, back to normal life...
This year’s Passover was quite the event. Hopefully, I’ll be able to host such a wonderful event like this again. We, the Children of Israel, must count our blessings indeed!
Passover Ends
Passover will soon end.
However, I can persist. It’s only a few days.
I can’t resist! Forgive me, [Root.Religion.GetRandomGodName]!

During Passover I’ve been trying very hard to not eat anything made with Chametz. But it is rather difficult! How can I eat delicious foods like soft, succulent breads and syrupy pastries? Sometimes, it’s just so hard to resist...
Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth - for thy love is better than wine.
Today, as part of Passover, we are all reciting the "Shir ha-Shirim" or the "Song of Songs." So we all begin to sing, in ancient Hebrew, "The song of songs, which is Solomon's..."
It's bland, but reminds me to be humble.
During Passover, instead of eating normal breads and such, we can only eat Matzo, made of unleavened grains. Matzo bread, matzo balls, matzo noodles, matzo fried with eggs...
There is much to think about here.

While the servants are cleaning up the remains of the seder meal, I observe the zroa laying on the table. It is a goat or sheep's shank bone, meant to represent the sacrifices once made and eaten in the Temple of Jerusalem during Passover in ancient times.
He will have to obey our laws.
We should respect his laws.

During this year's Passover, a Jewish merchant from a far-off land is also with us. However, the Jewish community he hails from has different kosher laws then us. His laws thus allow him to eat foods we can't on Passover, but some of my courtiers aren't pleased.
Oy vey!

During Passover, we usually eat bitter herbs to remind us of the bitterness our forebears experienced during the exodus from Egypt. Though I have done this many times before, it is always difficult to eat these herbs.
Restore the Temple.
The Jewish High Priesthood will be reestablished as the Temple is restored.
Romaniote

column2: Samaritan
Closely related to Judaism, yet also quite distinct. Samaritans claim that they represent the proper Israelite worship before the Babylonian Exile.
